recommendations: Perform a focused, contrast-enhanced CT angiography of the chest (arterial phase) to specifically assess the thoracic aorta. Omit abdominal and pelvic imaging unless clinically indicated.
Utilize a low-volume, weight-based contrast dose (approximately 80-100 mL of high-iodine-concentration agent) with a split-bolus or single-phase arterial protocol to minimize iodine load.
If hemodynamic instability precludes safe transport, consider bedside transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) or focused cardiac ultrasound as an alternative imaging modality.
Schedule follow-up renal labs (creatinine, eGFR) at 24 and 48 hours post-contrast to monitor for acute kidney injury.
rationale: Tailors imaging to the primary diagnosis of thoracic aorta injury, reducing unnecessary contrast exposure and scan time.
Minimizes nephrotoxic load in a hypotensive patient, aligning with ACR guidelines for contrast media.
Addresses the risk of transport in a critically ill, hypotensive patient by suggesting alternatives.
Essential for early detection of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in a patient with hemodynamic instability.

protocol_selection.name: CT Angiography — Thoracic Aorta
protocol_selection.description: Contrast-enhanced CT of the chest optimized for evaluation of the thoracic aorta, including aortic arch and descending aorta. Timed for arterial phase to best visualize lumen and wall.
protocol_selection.contrast_dose: Weight-based, ~80-100 mL of high-iodine-concentration (e.g., 370 mg I/mL) iodinated contrast. Consider split-bolus technique for optimal aortic opacification.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Use lowest effective volume and concentration. Confirm contrast-to-eGFR ratio. Monitor for signs of CIN. Consider iso-osmolar contrast if patient is volume depleted and fluid overload is a concern.
references: Traumatic Aortic Injury Protocol (Internal Hospital Guideline)

protocol_selection.name: Focused Bedside Echocardiography
protocol_selection.description: Point-of-care ultrasound performed at the bedside to assess cardiac function, identify gross structural abnormalities, and evaluate the aortic root and ascending aorta in cases where CT transport is contraindicated or delayed.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: No contrast or radiation exposure. Suitable for critically ill patients.
references: ACCF/ASE Guidelines for Performance Standards for Echocardiography
